I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will strengthen the design and 
implementation of country- and/or city-wide inclusive sanitation (CWIS) solutions in developing 
member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The TA will provide targeted 
support to facilitate investments in CWIS with the aim of increasing access to adequate and 
inclusive sanitation systems—whether sewered or non-sewered, centralized or decentralized—
where human waste is safely managed along the whole sanitation service chain. The TA is in line 
with Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 6.2 of achieving access to adequate and equitable 
sanitation solutions with special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable 
situations.1 
 
2.  The TA is included in the ADB Management-approved 2019 results-based work plan of 
ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department and will provide support to 
ADB’s water subsector operations to help achieve the goals of Strategy 2030, and in particular 
the following operational priorities: (i) addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities, (ii) 
accelerating progress in gender equality, (iii) making cities more livable, and (iv) promoting rural 
development and food security, (v) strengthening governance and institutional capacity.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Inadequate access to sanitation. In 2017, 1.2 billion people across Asia and the Pacific 
lacked access to basic sanitation services and 453 million people practiced open defecation,3 
which poses a huge challenge towards achieving SDG 6 (footnote 1). Out of these 1.2 billion 
people, almost 72% lived in rural areas while the rest lived in urban areas. Similarly, open 
defecation is still practiced by more people in rural areas (423 million) than in urban areas (30 
million). Aside from increased exposure to waterborne diseases, open defecation is particularly 
harmful for women, who are often exposing themselves to risks of violence, harassment, and 
physical abuse.4 On-site sanitation solutions such as latrines and septic tanks are predominant in 
Asia, where only a small fraction of the population is connected to sewerage systems comprising 
a network of sewer pipes directly connecting toilets to sewage (or wastewater) treatment plants. 
Only 18% of the population across Asia and the Pacific is connected to sewerage systems while 
40% uses on-site sanitation.5 
 
4.  Traditional approaches favor certain systems and locations. A large part of ADB 
sanitation investments has been focused on centralized sewerage systems, often in urbanized 
areas.6 Urbanization has outpaced planning, which is necessary for extensive underground piped 
networks. Piped sewer networks connected to a centralized wastewater treatment facility require 
large capital investments and a strong institutional framework for the operation and maintenance 
of the assets. In low-density peri-urban and rural areas, pipe networks are not as financially

5.  The Sanitation Financing Partnership Trust Fund (SFPTF)7 focused on supporting non-
sewered sanitation solutions or fecal sludge management for both urban and peri-urban areas.8 
Under the SFPTF, a five-pillar approach was adopted that comprised grant investments, piloting 
innovative technologies, building capacity of water and wastewater operators, developing policies 
and standards, and improving institutional awareness. This multipronged approach has leveraged 
a total of $133.7 million of investments in non-sewered sanitation solutions included in six 
investment projects in five DMCs.9 With the growing acceptance of fecal sludge management as 
a viable solution, ADB will leverage its track record in implementing sewerage projects to develop 
more integrated and inclusive sanitation projects. The TA builds on the various outputs and 
lessons from SFPTF-supported projects, which combined the support of investment projects with 
capacity  building  initiatives  hard  and  soft  investments  through  the  five-pillar  approach  for 
maximum impact. 
 
6.  Country- and/or city-wide inclusive sanitation concept. To achieve the SDG 6.2 
targets, it is necessary to adopt new approaches and to apply alternative sanitation concepts. The 
CWIS concept aims to provide equitable and inclusive sanitation services that address the 
realities found in developing countries. CWIS implies the following principles: (i) everyone, 
including people living in unserved, low-income, and vulnerable communities, benefits from 
equitable and safe sanitation service delivery outcomes; (ii) gender and social equity are included 
in planning, management, and monitoring; (iii) human wastes are safely managed along the whole 
sanitation service chain (capture, containment, emptying, transport, treatment, and safe reuse or 
disposal); (iv) authorities operate with a clear, inclusive mandate, performance targets, resources, 
and accountability; (v) a diversity of technical solutions is embraced for adaptive, mixed, and 
incremental  approaches  that  include  sewered  and  non-sewered  sanitation  solutions;  (vi) 
comprehensive long-term planning fosters demand for innovation and is informed by analysis of 
needs and resources; (vii) political will and accountability systems provide incentives for service 
improvements in planning, capacity, and leadership; and (viii) resource recovery and reuse of 
water, energy, and nutrients are considered (circular economy approach). The TA will help ADB 
to increase its efforts to facilitate communication and knowledge sharing of the CWIS concept 
among stakeholders. 
 
7.  There is a need to accelerate CWIS in DMCs through (i) developing holistic, integrated 
planning  and  design  approaches  that  consider  both  sewered  and  non-sewered  sanitation 
solutions; (ii) assessing and developing institutional arrangements to delineate responsibilities 
and ensure ownership and leadership of the government, and develop regulations, policies, and 
standards that address current and emerging trends, and their enforcement; (iii) determining 
optimal technical designs utilizing appropriate innovative technologies, resource recovery, and 
information technology applications; (iv) promoting knowledge sharing with development partners

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: access to adequate and equitable sanitation 
and hygiene achieved for all, and open defecation eliminated by 2030, with special attention to 
the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations (SDG 6.2) (footnote 1). The TA 
will have the following outcome: adoption of CWIS principles in ADB operations increased.11 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output  1:  Support  for  country-  and/or  city-wide  inclusive  sanitation  projects 
provided. This will be done in ADB operations by supporting (i) additional specialists who can 
provide  incremental  inputs  by  introducing  or  applying  CWIS  principles  in  planning  and 
implementation of projects, and (ii) resilience and circular economy initiatives for sustainability of 
investments. 
(i)  Pipeline  projects  on  water  supply  and  wastewater  management  or  flood 
management will be reviewed and supported to ensure that CWIS principles are 
considered.12 The TA will support ADB’s operations departments with necessary 
expertise to incorporate the principles of CWIS in project planning, design, and 
implementation.  Specifically,  the  TA  will  support  operations  departments  in 
developing equitable and inclusive sanitation solutions in urban and nonurban 
areas that take into account different, appropriate technologies and systems to 
ensure that human waste is safely managed along the whole sanitation service 
chain. As appropriate and as the demand arises, the TA may also support pilot 
testing of appropriate, innovative, and/or high-level sanitation technologies13 and 
service  delivery  methods,  which  may  include  public–private  partnerships  or 
systems and approaches that best demonstrate CWIS principles. 
(ii)  The TA will promote sustainability and resilience by identifying project risks and 
vulnerabilities and developing resilience strategies and responses to disasters. 
When appropriate, circular economy principles which reuse water, energy, and 
nutrients will be incorporated in project designs to increase focus on minimizing 
waste and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. 
____________________

been arrived at by looking at the current pipeline, work program, and budget framework and discussions with project 
officers to identify possible opportunities for incorporating CWIS.

10.  Output 2: Knowledge on country- and/or city-wide inclusive sanitation principles 
improved. The TA will provide support to operations departments to develop CWIS policy 
documents and implementation guidelines, monitoring frameworks, indicators, and case studies. 
For ADB DMCs, the TA will provide guidance to strengthen policies, regulations, and best 
practices  to  promote  CWIS  principles,  and  capacity  building  for  enforcing  regulations  and 
strengthening  government  leadership.  This  will  include  mainstreaming  CWIS  principles  in 
sanitation master plans and incorporating CWIS principles in local sanitation codes or ordinances, 
which will require development of guidelines on monitoring and tracking; promotion of progressive 
financial strategies; and development of business models, operation and maintenance manuals, 
and protocols. Working with other partners, the TA will develop guidelines, regulations, policies, 
and toolkits such as a CWIS draft monitoring framework that can design and monitor CWIS 
indicators at portfolio and project level. 
 
11.  Output  3:  Country-  and/or  city-wide  inclusive  sanitation  related  capacity  and 
awareness  in  developing  member  countries  improved.  The  TA  will  contribute  to 
mainstreaming  sanitation  and  the  CWIS  concept  in  ADB’s  operations,  and  to  promoting 
continuous learning and networking on CWIS. ADB will utilize its best practices, such as the Water 
Operators Partnerships Program, to complement planned and ongoing CWIS initiatives and to 
improve operational knowledge to deliver sanitation services, including regulatory practices. This 
will be done by pairing a developing water operator recipient with a water utility mentor with 
advanced experience and proven success in effective, efficient service delivery who can impart 
operational knowledge to the recipient through on-the-job training. Knowledge-sharing events, 
such as ADB’s Asian Sanitation Dialogue, will be conducted to raise awareness of and advocate 
for CWIS. Together with ADB’s operations departments, in-country dialogues and peer-to-peer 
learning will be conducted to promote the CWIS concept in ADB’s DMCs. Knowledge sharing, 
including dissemination of CWIS publications and studies, will be integral to promoting the 
concept in ADB operations and DMCs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $5 million, of which (i) $3 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the SFPTF14 under the Water Financing Partnership Facility (WFPF), and (ii) $2 million 
will be financed on a grant basis by the Urban Climate Change Resilience Trust Fund (UCCRTF)15 
under the Urban Financing Partnership Facility, both administered by ADB. Key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2. Expenses listed in Appendix 2 are eligible under the respective guidelines 
of the SFPTF and the UCCRTF. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA and will be the executing agency. In close coordination with 
the operations departments, resident missions, and other sector and thematic groups, the Water 
Sector Group under the Sector Advisory Services Cluster of ADB’s Sustainable Development and 
Climate  Change  Department  will  implement  the  TA  and  will  carry  out  TA  administration, 
implementation supervision, and communication with consultants and other entities engaged 
through the TA.

15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff  instructions.16 Sanitation  management  practitioners  specializing  in  project  design  and 
development,  asset  management,  knowledge  management,  operations,  opportunities,  and 
business development will be engaged to respond to demands from operations departments. 
Through a memo application, project officers may request to engage specialists to support each 
project. Once the application is approved, project officers will be responsible for recruiting experts, 
managing contracts and output, ensuring timely disbursement, and providing ADB’s Sustainable 
Development and Climate Change Department with progress updates.  
 
16.  Cofinancier requirements. The WFPF semiannual and annual reports are provided to 
comply with the monitoring and reporting requirements of the SFPTF. In addition, a detailed 
progress report on the SFPTF-supported projects are provided as a supplement to the WFPF 
reports. For a TA project, the UCCRTF requires gender-disaggregated data reports on activities 
related to consultations and capacity building. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent 
of $3,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Sanitation Financing Partnership Trust Fund 
under the Water Financing Partnership Facility; and (ii) ADB administering technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Urban Climate 
Change Resilience Trust Fund under the Urban Financing Partnership Facility for Accelerating 
Sanitation for All in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
